--- title: "Data visualization" format: revealjs: theme: simple smaller: true slide-number: true # incremental: true # code-link: true chalkboard: true history: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Overview ::::: columns ::: {.column style="font-size: smaller;"} 1. **The `ggplot` function** 2. **Mapping data to aesthetics** 3. **Different geoms** 4. **Scales** ::: ::: {.column style="font-size: smaller;"} 5. **Facets** 6. **Coordinates** 7. **Themes** ::: ::::: # The `ggplot` function --- ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: r-stack `tidyverse`{.fragment .fade-out fragment-index="1"} `ggplot`{.fragment .fade-in fragment-index="1"} ::: :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: r-stack ![](images/tidyverse.png){.fragment .semi-fade-out width="500" fragment-index="1"} ![](images/ggplot.png){.fragment .fade-in .absolute fragment-index="1" width="200" top="40" right="250"} ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## The `ggplot()` function ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="70%"} `ggplot()` from the `ggplot2` package is what we're gonna use for all our plots It takes the following core arguments: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data, aes()) + geometry + other_stuff ``` ::: - **Data**: the values to plot - **Mapping** (aes, for aesthetics): the structure of the plot - **Geometry**: the type of plot :::{.fragment} You can also use a pipe ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data |> ggplot(aes()) + geometry + other_stuff ``` ::: ::: :::: :::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/ggplot.png){width="300"} :::: ::::::: --- ## The `ggplot()` function Take for instance the gapminder data you've previously installed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code .code-overflow-wrap} library(gapminder) # The data() function in R is used to list, load, # and access built-in or package-provided datasets. data(gapminder) ``` ::: Let's get a quick overview of the data again. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(gapminder) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 6 country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap 1 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.8 8425333 779. 2 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.3 9240934 821. 3 Afghanistan Asia 1962 32.0 10267083 853. 4 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.0 11537966 836. 5 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.1 13079460 740. 6 Afghanistan Asia 1977 38.4 14880372 786. ``` ::: ::: --- ## What's the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita?

... we expect of course that higher GDP per capita leads to greater life expactancy. --- ## What's the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita? ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - We first assign the gapminder data to `ggplot()` - The result is just an empty plot :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## What's the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita? ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - Next, we map out the plot by adding the x and y axes :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## What's the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita? ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - We then define how we want to plot our data - In this case, let's go for the raw data points :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Mapping data to aesthetics So far, only two variables appear in our plot (mapped onto the x and the y axis)
But we can add more variables to the plot, by assigning them to certain asthetics --- ## Mapping data to aesthetics ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - For example, we can display the variable continent as colors :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Mapping data to aesthetics ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - For example, we can display the variable continent as colors - Note that a legend gets added automatically to the plot :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Mapping data to aesthetics ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} - We could further display population size by mapping it to the size aesthetic :::: :::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Grammatical Layers ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} So far we know about data, aesthetics, and geometries
Think of these components as **layers**
We add them to foundational `ggplot()` with `+` :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/ggplot-layers-short@4x.png) :::: ::::::: --- ## Possible aesthetics ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="30%"} `color` (discrete) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-color-discrete-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: `color` (continuous) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-color-continuous-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: :::: :::: {.column width="30%"} `size` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-size-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: `fill` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-fill-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: :::: :::: {.column width="30%"} `shape` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-shape-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: `alpha` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/aes-alpha-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Possible geoms
Example geom What it makes
geom_col() Bar charts
geom_text() Text
geom_point() Points
geom_boxplot()  Boxplots
geom_sf() Maps
--- ## Possible geoms There are dozens of possible geoms and
each class session will cover different ones.
See [the {ggplot2} documentation](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/index.html#section-layer-geoms) for complete examples of all the different geom layers --- ## Additional Layers ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="40%"} There are many of other grammatical layers we can use to describe graphs! We sequentially add layers onto the foundational `ggplot()` plot to create complex figures :::: :::: {.column width="60%"} ![](images/ggplot-layers@4x.png) :::: ::::::: --- ## Scales Scales change how variables are mapped
Example layer What it does
scale_x_continuous() Make the x-axis continuous
scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:5)  Manually specify axis ticks
scale_x_log10() Log the x-axis
scale_color_gradient() Use a gradient
scale_fill_viridis_d() Fill with discrete viridis colors
--- ## Scales ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Scales ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="5"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Scales ::: {.cell .column-screen-inset output-location='column' output-width='150%'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="6"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Facets Facets show subplots for different subsets of data
Example layer What it does
facet_wrap(vars(continent)) Plot for each continent
facet_wrap(vars(continent, year))  Plot for each continent/year
facet_wrap(..., ncol = 1) Put all facets in one column
facet_wrap(..., nrow = 1) Put all facets in one row
--- ## Facets ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Facets ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="7"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() + facet_wrap(vars(continent)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Facets ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2,9"} ggplot(data = gapminder |> filter(year %in% c(2002, 2007)), mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() + facet_wrap(vars(continent, year), nrow = 2) ``` ::: :::: :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::: ::::::: --- ## Coordinates Change the coordinate system
Example layer What it does
coord_cartesian() Plot for each continent
coord_cartesian(ylim = c(1, 10))  Zoom in where y is 1–10
coord_flip() Switch x and y
coord_polar() Use circular polar system
--- ## Coordinates ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Coordinates ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="7,8"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() + coord_cartesian(ylim = c(70, 80), xlim = c(10000, 30000)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Coordinates ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="7"} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Labels Add labels to the plot with a single `labs()` layer
Example layer What it does

labs(caption = "Something") Caption
labs(y = "Something") y-axis
labs(size = "Population") Title of size legend

::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder, mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, color = continent, size = pop)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10() + scale_color_viridis_d() + labs(title = "Health and wealth grow together", subtitle = "Data from the world", x = "Wealth (GDP per capita)", y = "Health (life expectancy)", color = "Continent", size = "Population", caption = "Source: The Gapminder Project") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Theme options Make theme adjustments with `theme()` There are a billion options here! <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
